net.openhft.chronicle.queue

Enum RollCycles

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Enum<RollCycles>
      • net.openhft.chronicle.queue.RollCycles
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Comparable<RollCycles>, RollCycle

    public enum RollCycles
extends Enum<RollCycles>
implements RollCycle
    Roll cycles to use with the queue. Sparse indexing roll cycles are useful for improving write performance but they slightly slow random access performance (with no effect for sequential reads)

    • Enum Constant Summary

      Enum Constants 
      Enum Constant and Description
      DAILY
      0xffffffff entries per day, indexing every 64th entry, leave as 8K and 64 for historical reasons.
      FAST_DAILY
      0xffffffff entries per day, indexing every 256th entry, leave as 4K and 256 for historical reasons.
      FAST_HOURLY
      0xffffffff entries per hour, indexing every 256th entry, leave as 4K and 256 for historical reasons.
      FIVE_MINUTELY
      0x40000000 entries per 5 minutes, indexing every 256th entry
      FOUR_HOURLY
      0xffffffff entries per four hours, indexing every 256th entry
      HALF_HOURLY
      0x40000000 entries per half hour, indexing every 256th entry
      HOURLY
      0x10000000 entries per hour, indexing every 16th entry, leave as 4K and 16 for historical reasons.
      HUGE_DAILY
      0xffffffffffff entries per day with sparse indexing (every 1024th entry)
      HUGE_DAILY_XSPARSE
      0xffffffffffff entries per day with super-sparse indexing (every (2^20)th entry)
      LARGE_DAILY
      0x1fffffffff entries per day, indexing every 128th entry
      LARGE_HOURLY
      0xffffffff entries per hour, indexing every 64th entry
      LARGE_HOURLY_SPARSE
      0x3ffffffff entries per hour with sparse indexing (every 1024th entry)
      LARGE_HOURLY_XSPARSE
      0x3ffffffffff entries per hour with super-sparse indexing (every (2^20)th entry)
      MINUTELY
      0x4000000 entries per minute, indexing every 16th entry
      SIX_HOURLY
      0xffffffff entries per six hours, indexing every 256th entry
      SMALL_DAILY
      0x20000000 entries per day, indexing every 8th entry
      TEN_MINUTELY
      0x40000000 entries per 10 minutes, indexing every 256th entry
      TEST_DAILY
      0x40 entries per day - Only good for testing
      TEST_HOURLY
      0x400 entries per hour - Only good for testing
      TEST_SECONDLY
      0xffffffff entries - Only good for testing
      TEST2_DAILY
      0x200 entries per day - Only good for testing
      TEST4_DAILY
      0x1000 entries per day - Only good for testing
      TEST4_SECONDLY
      0x1000 entries - Only good for testing
      TEST8_DAILY
      0x20000 entries per day - Only good for testing
      TWENTY_MINUTELY
      0x40000000 entries per 20 minutes, indexing every 256th entry
      TWO_HOURLY
      0xffffffff entries per 2 hours, indexing every 256th entry
      XLARGE_DAILY
      0x3ffffffffff entries per day, indexing every 256th entry

      • all

      • format

        public String format()
        Description copied from interface: RollCycle
        Returns the format that is to be applied when file names are calculated for a new roll cycle.

        For example, the following formats can be returned:

        • "yyyyMMdd-HHmm" (MINUTELY)
        • "yyyyMMdd" (DAILY)
        Specified by:
        format in interface RollCycle
        Returns:
        the format that is to be applied when file names are calculated for a new roll cycle

      • lengthInMillis

        public int lengthInMillis()
        Description copied from interface: RollCycle
        Returns the length in milliseconds (i.e. the maximum duration) for a roll cycle.

        For example, the following lengths can be returned:

        • 60 * 1,000 = 60,000 (MINUTELY)
        • 24 * 60 * 60 * 1,000 = 86,400,000 (DAILY)
        Specified by:
        lengthInMillis in interface RollCycle
        Returns:
        the length in milliseconds (i.e. the maximum duration) for a roll cycle

      • defaultIndexCount

        public int defaultIndexCount()
        Specified by:
        defaultIndexCount in interface RollCycle
        Returns:
        this is the size of each index array, note: indexCount^2 is the maximum number of index queue entries.

      • defaultIndexSpacing

        public int defaultIndexSpacing()
        Description copied from interface: RollCycle
        Returns the space between excerpts that are explicitly indexed.

        A higher number means higher sequential write performance but slower random access read. The sequential read performance is not affected by this property.

        For example, the following default index spacing can be returned:

        • 16 (MINUTELY)
        • 64 (DAILY)
        Specified by:
        defaultIndexSpacing in interface RollCycle
        Returns:
        the space between excerpts that are explicitly indexed

      • current

        public int current(@NotNull
                   @NotNull net.openhft.chronicle.core.time.TimeProvider time,
                   long epoch)
        Description copied from interface: RollCycle
        Returns the current cycle. Default epoch is 0 so for a DAILY cycle this will return the number of days since 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z.
        Specified by:
        current in interface RollCycle
        epoch - an EPOCH offset, to all the user to define their own epoch
        Returns:
        the current cycle

      • toIndex

        public long toIndex(int cycle,
                    long sequenceNumber)
        Description copied from interface: RollCycle
        Returns the index for the provided cycle and sequenceNumber.

        An index is made up of cycle shifted left + sequenceNumber. sequenceNumber starts at 0 for each new cycle. DAILY cycle has cycleShift=32 and sequenceMask=0xFFFFFFFF so the top 32 bits are for cycle and bottom 32 bits are for sequence. This means you can only store 2^32 entries per day. HUGE_DAILY has shift=48 and mask=0xFFFFFFFFFFFF thus allowing 2^48 entries per day.

        Specified by:
        toIndex in interface RollCycle
        Parameters:
        cycle - to be composed into an index
        sequenceNumber - to be composed into an index
        Returns:
        the index for the given cycle and sequenceNumber

      • toSequenceNumber

        public long toSequenceNumber(long index)
        Description copied from interface: RollCycle
        Returns the sequence number for the provided index.

        An index is comprised of both a cycle and a sequence number but the way the index is composed of said properties may vary. This method decomposes the provided index and extracts the sequence number.

        Specified by:
        toSequenceNumber in interface RollCycle
        Parameters:
        index - to use to extract the sequence number
        Returns:
        the sequence number for the provided index

      • toCycle

        public int toCycle(long index)
        Description copied from interface: RollCycle
        Returns the cycle for the given index.

        An index is comprised of both a cycle and a sequence number but the way the index is composed of said properties may vary. This method decomposes the provided index and extracts the cycle.

        Specified by:
        toCycle in interface RollCycle
        Parameters:
        index - to use when extracting the cycle
        Returns:
        the sequence number for the given index
